title-group.article-title: Interaction between BDNF rs6265 met allele and low family cohesion is associated with smaller left hippocampal volume in pediatric bipolar disorder

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, University of Texas Center of Excellence on Mood Disorders, Houston, TX, USA
2Department of Diagnostic and Interventional Imaging, UT Houston Medical School, Houston, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Cristian P. Zeni, M.D., Ph.D., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, The University of Texas Health Science Center, 1941 East Road, Houston, TX 77054 - USA, Cristian.P.Zeni@uth.tmc.edu

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Genetic and environmental factors are implicated in the onset and evolution of pediatric bipolar disorder, and may be associated to structural brain abnormalities. The aim of our study was to assess the impact of the interaction between the Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) rs6265 polymorphism and family functioning on hippocampal volumes of children and adolescents with bipolar disorder, and typically-developing controls.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We evaluated the family functioning cohesion subscale using the Family Environment Scale-Revised, genotyped the BDNF rs6265 polymorphism, and performed structural brain imaging in 29 children and adolescents with bipolar disorder, and 22 healthy controls.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We did not find significant differences between patients with BD or controls in left or right hippocampus volume (p=0.44, and p=0.71, respectively). However, we detected a significant interaction between low scores on the cohesion subscale and the presence of the Met allele at BNDF on left hippocampal volume of patients with bipolar disorder (F=3.4, p=0.043). None of the factors independently (BDNF Val66Met, cohesion scores) was significantly associated with hippocampal volume differences.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: These results may lead to a better understanding of the impact of the interaction between genes and environment factors on brain structures associated to bipolar disorder and its manifestations.
